abstracts.cdata!:
The audit downgrades the Implementation
            Completion Report's project outcome ratings, from
            satisfactory to moderately satisfactory, although it concurs
            with its likely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impact ratings. Lessons of experience are
            suggested as follows. During implementation, it is important
            to maintain the balance between the construction of
            infrastructure, and institutional strengthening in
            accordance with priorities established in the project
            design. Notwithstanding, in extraordinary circumstances,
            such as following a major interruption in implementation,
            substantial revisions or adjustments to the project
            components may be needed. This project provides a good
            example of how new demand projections, and corresponding
            changes in project design can be called upon, under
            drastically changing conditions, through implementation of a
            careful review and appropriate revisions. In this case, it
            should have taken place around 1995 (after the war) when the
            project was re-launched for final implementation.
            Furthermore, the implementation plan for reducing
            unaccounted water, including detailed annual targets, needs
            to be specified in the project preparation documents. Had
            this plan been better designed with detailed annual targets,
            its implementation and supervision would have been less
            disrupted by the difficult wartime circumstances.
